S3.T1.caption: Table 1: The cross-domain evaluation of SynFace and RealFace using the metric of face verification accuracy (%percent\%).
S3.T1.table:
Method Training Dataset LFW Syn-LFW
RealFace CASIA-WebFace 99.18 98.85
SynFace Syn_10K_50 88.98 99.98
references: To explore the performance gap between SynFace and RealFace, as well as the underlying causes, we perform experiments on real-world face datasets and synthetic face datasets generated by DiscoFaceGAN [12]. Specifically, for real-world face datasets, we use CASIA-WebFace [64] for training and LFW [27] for testing. For the fair comparison, we generate the synthetic version of the LFW dataset, Syn-LFW, using the same parameters (the number of samples, the number of identities, distributions of expression, pose, and illumination). For synthetic training data, we generate 10​K10𝐾10K different identities with 505050 samples per identity to form a comparable training dataset to CASIA-WebFace (containing 494,414 images from 10,575 subjects) and we refer to it as Syn_10K_50. More details of synthetic dataset construction can be found in Sec. 4.1. With both synthetic and real face images, we then perform the cross-domain evaluation as follows. We train two face recognition models on CASIA-WebFace and Syn_10K_50, and test them on LFW and Syn-LFW, respectively. As shown in Table 1, there is a clear performance gap (88.98%percent88.9888.98\% vs. 99.18%percent99.1899.18\%) when testing on LFW, while SynFace outperforms RealFace on Syn-LFW (99.98%percent99.9899.98\% vs. 98.85%percent98.8598.85\%). These observations suggest that the domain gap between synthetic and real face images contributes to the performance gap between SynFace and RealFace.

To evaluate the identity mixup for enlarging the intra-class variations, as illustrated in Figure 3, we visualize the feature embedding distributions of the same class in three synthetic datasets (containing 5​K5𝐾5K different identities with 505050 samples per identity) with different levels of identity mixup (IM) by using multidimensional scaling (MDS [4]). Note that Syn1, Syn2 and Syn3 represent the weighted ratio φ𝜑\varphi is 1.0 (i.e., no IM), 0.8 and randomly sampled from the linear space which varies from 0.60.60.6 to 1.01.01.0 with the interval being 0.05 (i.e., n​p.l​i​n​s​p​a​c​e​(0.6,1.0,11)formulae-sequence𝑛𝑝𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑠𝑝𝑎𝑐𝑒0.61.011np.linspace(0.6,1.0,11)). It is clear that the cyan triangles (Syn1) have the smallest variations , while the red circles (Syn3) have the largest one and the blue squares (Syn2) are in the middle position. Accordingly, the accuracy is in an increasing trend (i.e., 88.75%→89.47%→90.95%→percent88.75percent89.47→percent90.9588.75\%\rightarrow 89.47\%\rightarrow 90.95\%). Besides, 88.98%percent88.9888.98\% (as in Table 1) is boosted to 91.97%percent91.9791.97\% (as in Table 2) after utilizing identity mixup. In particular, when the baseline is weaker, the improvement brought by identity mixup is larger, which are shown in Table 3 and Figure 7.

It is clear that the cyan triangles (Syn1) have the smallest variations , while the red circles (Syn3) have the largest one and the blue squares (Syn2) are in the middle position. Accordingly, the accuracy is in an increasing trend (i.e., 88.75%→89.47%→90.95%→percent88.75percent89.47→percent90.9588.75\%\rightarrow 89.47\%\rightarrow 90.95\%). where XS,XRsubscript𝑋𝑆subscript𝑋𝑅X_{S},X_{R} indicate the synthetic and real face images, respectively, and YS,YRsubscript𝑌𝑆subscript𝑌𝑅Y_{S},Y_{R} indicate their corresponding labels. Note that ψ𝜓\psi is the mixup ratio which is randomly sampled from the linear space distribution from 0.00.00.0 to 1.01.01.0 with the interval being 0.05 (i.e., n​p.l​i​n​s​p​a​c​e​(0.0,1.0,21)formulae-sequence𝑛𝑝𝑙𝑖𝑛𝑠𝑝𝑎𝑐𝑒0.01.021np.linspace(0.0,1.0,21)). For the large-scale synthetic data, we synthesize the Syn_10K_50 dataset that has 10​K10𝐾10K different identities with 505050 samples per identity. For a small set of real-world data, we utilize the first 2​K2𝐾2K identities of CASIA-WebFace. The experimental results are shown in Table 2. Specifically, the first row, Syn_10K_50, indicating the baseline method without using any real face images, achieves the accuracy 91.97%percent91.9791.97\% using identity mixup. “Real_N_S” means the use of only real images, N𝑁N identities with S𝑆S samples per identity during training, while “Mix_N_S” indicates a mixture of N𝑁N real identities with S𝑆S samples per identity with Syn_10K_50 during training. Both identity mixup and domain mixup are employed on all the ‘Mix_N_S” datasets. As demonstrated in Table 2, domain mixup brings a significant and consistent improvement over the baseline methods under different settings. For example, Mix_2K_10 obtains 95.78%percent95.7895.78\% accuracy, which significantly surpasses 91.97%percent91.9791.97\% achieved by Syn_10K_50 and 91.22%percent91.2291.22\% achieved by Real_2K_10. We conjecture that mixup with the real images can bring the real-world appearance attributes (e.g., blur and illumination) to synthetic images, which alleviate the domain gap. If we continue to increase the number of real images for training, e.g., Mix_2K_20, the performance can be further boosted from 95.78%percent95.7895.78\% to 97.65%percent97.6597.65\%.

Empirical Analysis.
We train the same face recognition model on these synthetic datasets, and the experimental results (both w/wo identity mixup) are shown in Table 3. Firstly, we analyze the influence of the width of the dataset by comparing the results of (a),(b),(c),(i)𝑎𝑏𝑐𝑖(a),~{}(b),~{}(c),~{}(i). From (a)𝑎(a) to (c)𝑐(c), we see that the accuracy dramatically increases from 83.85%percent83.8583.85\% to 88.75%percent88.7588.75\%. However, the improvement is marginal from (c)𝑐(c) to (i)𝑖(i), which implies that the synthetic data may suffer from the lack of inter-class variations. Observing the results of (d),(e),(f),(g),(h),(i)𝑑𝑒𝑓𝑔ℎ𝑖(d),~{}(e),~{}(f),~{}(g),~{}(h),~{}(i), we conclude that the accuracy significantly increases with the increasing of dataset depth, but it is quickly saturated when the depth is larger than 202020, which is in line with the observation on real data made by Schroff et al. [46]. Lastly, we see that (a)𝑎(a) and (e)𝑒(e) have the same number of total images (50K), while (a)𝑎(a) outperforms (e)𝑒(e) with a large margin, i.e., 4.37%percent4.374.37\%, which reveals that the dataset width plays as the more important role than the dataset depth in term of the final face recognition accuracy. Similar observation can be found by comparing (b)𝑏(b) and (f)𝑓(f). Importantly, employing the identity mixup (IM) for training consistently improves the performance over all the datasets, which confirms the effectiveness of IM. The best accuracy 91.97%percent91.9791.97\% brought by IM significantly outperforms the original 88.98%percent88.9888.98\%.
